member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.Archetype
member.summary:
An store entities with a specific set of and types.
See Example.
member.remarks:
E.g. all entities with a and component are store in the same archetype.
In case of removing one of these components or adding a new one from / to an the entity is moved to a different archetype.
This is the basic pattern for an archetype base ECS. This approach enables efficient entity / component queries.
A query result is simply the union of all archetypes having the requested components.
Queries can be created via generic .Query() methods.

member.name: M:Friflo.Engine.ECS.EntityStoreBase.Batch(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Returns a used to create entities with components and tags added to the batch.
See Example.
member.remarks:
The returned batch creates an entity with previously added components and tags when calling .
If == true the batch is returned to the EntityStore when calling .
Subsequent use of the batch throws .
If == false can be called multiple times to create multiple entities.
The caller should call after usage to prevent unnecessary memory allocations.
When calling or the batch executes without memory allocations.

member.summary:
Safe alternative for unsafe variant using to create a span of a single item.
The general problem of this approach, the item is typically on the stack.
So it's easy to create code with access violation that reference the span item that is not on the stack anymore.

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.Serialize.DataEntity
member.summary: A represents an as a POCO class used for serialization.
member.remarks:
When reading / writing 's in the editor a special MemoryDatabase" implementation is required.
This implementation preserves the order of entities stored in a JSON file.
Therefor it stores the order of each entity when loaded and apply this order when writing them back to the JSON file.
Having a stable order is required avoid merge conflicts.
Otherwise the entity order in a JSON file would be arbitrary.
Even small changes will show a massive diff in version control.

member.name: F:Friflo.Engine.ECS.Serialize.DataEntity.pid
member.summary: Permanent id used to identify entities in a database

member.name: F:Friflo.Engine.ECS.Serialize.DataEntity.children
member.summary: The list of child entity ids.
member.remarks:
Used a list of child ids instead of a single field parentId to enable child order.
An alternative order implementation - using firstChild, nextSibling - is error prone if referenced nodes are missing.
For now the child order is required to enable a memorable order in the editor and to avoid merge conflicts.

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.Collections.ExplorerItem
member.summary:
Implements same interfaces as to act as a replacement for this container class using the generic type .
This enables displaying and mutation of 's in a Avalonia.Controls.TreeDataGrid.
A specialized implementation of this control is the ExplorerTreeDataGrid in this repository.
member.remarks:
It seems a common and reasonable approach that other UI frameworks like MAUI or UNO Platform provide
TreeView controls by using TreeView items implementing and optionally .
Major advantages of this approach.
Support millions of items within a TreeView hierarchy without any UI stuttering.
Enabling binding hierarchical data to a UI without the need of 3rd party libraries in the data layer.
and optionally of the BCL are sufficient.

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.EntityBatch
member.summary:
An entity batch is a container of component and tag commands that can be 'ed to an entity.
It can be used on a single entity via or as a bulk operation an a set of entities.
member.remarks:
Its purpose is to optimize add / remove component and tag changes on entities.
The same entity changes can be performed with the methods using:
, , or .
Each of these methods may cause a structural change which is a relative costly operation in comparison to others.
Using a batch minimize theses structural changes to one or none.
Bulk operation
To perform a batch on multiple entities you can use for
- the entities of an using . See Example.
- all entities of an using .
- or the entities of an using .
To perform a batch on entities in an you can use . See Example.

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.Unresolved
member.summary: is a container for unresolved entity components.
member.remarks:
An component is added to an by if:
A component in . cannot be resolved to an or type.
A tag in . cannot be resolved to an type.
The component enables conversion of a to an and vice versa
with components or tags that cannot be resolved to , and types.
Having support component or tag types:
Ensures the ability to use an containing unresolved types without being blocked by a missing fix.
Prevents data loss of tags or components when storing an with entities containing unresolved tag or component types.
The reason for unresolved tag or component types can be:
Missed to merge C# code containing an , an or type definition.
Intentionally when creating an with external tools without the need to wait for the implementation of new
, an or type definitions.

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.Entity
member.summary:
Represent an object in an - e.g. a cube in a game scene.
It is the main API to deal with entities in the engine.
See Example.

remarks.para:
Every has an and is a container of , 's, 's and other child 's.
Comparison to other game engines.
Unity - an provides a similar features set as a GameObject and their ECS Entity.
Godot - is the counterpart of a Node.
The key difference is Godot is an OOP architecture inheriting from Node over multiple levels.
FLAX - is the counterpart of an Actor - an OOP architecture like Godot.
STRIDE - is the counterpart of a STRIDE Entity - a component based architecture like Unity.
In contrast to this engine or Unity it has no ECS architecture - Entity Component System.

Components
An is typically an object that can be rendered on screen like a cube, sphere, capsule, mesh, sprite, ... .
Therefore a renderable component needs to be added with to an .
Child entities
An can be added to another using .
The added becomes a child of the it is added to - its .
This enables to build up a complex game scene with a hierarchy of 's.
The order of children contained by an entity is the insertion order.
Scripts
A 's can be added to an to add custom logic (script) and data to an entity.
's are added or removed with / .
Tags
can be added to an to enable filtering entities in queries.
By adding to an it can be restricted to return only entities matching the these .
Events
All entity changes - aka mutations - can be observed for specific 's and the whole .
In detail the following changes can be observed.
type entity event event argument action
component
, ,
script
, ,
tags
,
child entity
,

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.EntityNode
member.summary: Used by the to store components, scripts, tags and child entities internally as an array of nodes.
member.remarks:
's enable organizing entities in a tree graph structure.
The tree graph is stored in a starting with a single entity.
When creating a new entity in an instantiated with it generates a unique random pid assigned to the entity.
Using random pids avoid merge conflicts when multiples users make changes to the same file / database.
The probability generating the same pid by two different users is:
p = 1 - exp(-r^2 / (2 * N)) r: number of new entities added by a user to an existing (not the number of all entities) N: number of possible values = int.MaxValue = 2147483647
See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birthday_problem

member.remarks:
- SEND_EVENT notes -
Send event must be last statement AFTER an entity mutation has finished.
This ensures preserving a valid entity state after an add / remove mutation has finished.
Reasons:
- Event handlers expect a valid entity state after add / remove mutation.
- When sending an event to the event handlers any of them may throw an exception. So this exception will not result in an invalid entity state.
The entity state refers to:

member.summary: Specify the way how an generates entity 's.

member.name: F:Friflo.Engine.ECS.PidType.UsePidAsId
member.summary:
Used to simplify testing as the pid and id of an entity are equal.
It also increases performance in case ids are consecutively.
This method is not intended to be used to store entities of an in JSON files or in a database.
member.remarks:
Disadvantages:
- Big gaps between ids are wasted memory.
- When add entities in a database id clashes with entities added by other users are very likely.
- High probability of merge conflicts caused by id clashes by adding the same entity ids by multiple users.

member.summary:
Map random 's to 's used within the engine at runtime.
This method is intended to be used to store entities of an in JSON files or in a database.

's are used to emit custom events from an entity to custom handlers.

handlers are added with .

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.ParallelJobRunner
member.summary:
Required for parallel - multi threaded - query job execution using .
See Example.
member.remarks:
is thread safe.
The intention is to use the same instance for all jobs. E.g. the JobRunner assigned to the .
The job runner divide a job in multiple tasks each executed on its own core.
This ensures high cache hit rate of code and data structures.
Constraint
When executing nested jobs - running a job within another job - the nested job requires its own runner.
Performance related implementation goals:
- Minimize calls to synchronization primitives.
- Use cheap synchronization primitives such as: , and .
- Minimize thread context switches caused by in case calling when the event is not signaled.
Note: To analyze the amount of thread context switches use: Process Explorer > Column > CSwitch Delta.

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.QueryJob
member.summary:
A enables query execution using multiple threads to reduce execution time of large queries.
They are created by the ArchetypeQuery.ForEach() methods.
member.remarks:
To execute a query job use the method.
To execute a query job use the method.

member.name: P:Friflo.Engine.ECS.QueryJob.JobRunner
member.summary: The job runner used to execute a query .

member.name: P:Friflo.Engine.ECS.QueryJob.MinParallelChunkLength
member.summary:
The minimum number of components per thread required to execute a query .
Default: 1000.
member.remarks:
Parallel query execution adds an overhead of 1 to 2 micro seconds per query for thread synchronization.
Execution of a simple computation like health.value++ on a single component takes 0.5 to 1 nano seconds.
E.g. processing a chunk with 100 components will take 50 to 100 nano seconds.
So the chunk components are executed to avoid the parallelization overhead.
For more complex computations can be reduced to execute a query when dealing with a lower number of components.

This enables vectorization using Vector128, Vector256 or Vector512 without a remainder loop.

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.RawEntityNode
member.remarks:
Hard rule
All fields must be blittable types. As the intention is to store millions (or billions) of 's in ..
This enables that the GC will not iterate when performing a GC.Collect().

member.name: T:Friflo.Engine.ECS.RawEntityStore
member.summary: A enables using an entity store without using 's.
member.remarks:
The focus of the this entity store implementation is performance.
The key is to minimize heap consumption required by 's - 48 bytes
A stores only an array of blittable 's - structs having no reference type fields.
The downside of this approach are:
Entities can be created only programmatically but not within the editor which requires (managed) 's.
The API to access / query / mutate 's is less convenient.
It requires always two parameters - a + entity id - instead of a single reference.

member.summary:
To enable adding a script class to an it need to extend .
See Example.
member.remarks:
A is a reference type - a class- which contains data and behavior - aka scripts / methods.
An can contain multiple 's but only one of each type.
's can be used if OPP programming approach is preferred and dealing with less than a few 1.000 instances.
Optionally attribute the extended class with
to assign a custom component key name used for JSON serialization.
Info: Its functionality is similar to a class extending MonoBehaviour added to a GameObject in Unity.

member.summary: Gets the identifier of the analysis tool rule to be suppressed.
member.remarks: Concatenated together, the and properties form a unique check identifier.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Scope
member.summary: Gets or sets the scope of the code that is relevant for the attribute.
member.remarks: The Scope property is an optional argument that specifies the metadata scope for which the attribute is relevant.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Target
member.summary: Gets or sets a fully qualified path that represents the target of the attribute.
member.remarks: The property is an optional argument identifying the analysis target of the attribute. An example value is "System.IO.Stream.ctor():System.Void". Because it is fully qualified, it can be long, particularly for targets such as parameters. The analysis tool user interface should be capable of automatically formatting the parameter.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.MessageId
member.summary: Gets or sets an optional argument expanding on exclusion criteria.
member.remarks: The property is an optional argument that specifies additional exclusion where the literal metadata target is not sufficiently precise. For example, the cannot be applied within a method, and it may be desirable to suppress a violation against a statement in the method that will give a rule violation, but not against all statements in the method.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Justification
member.summary: Gets or sets the justification for suppressing the code analysis message.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that certain members on a specified are accessed dynamically, for example through .
member.remarks:
This allows tools to understand which members are being accessed during the execution of a program.
This attribute is valid on members whose type is or .
When this attribute is applied to a location of type , the assumption is that the string represents a fully qualified type name.
When this attribute is applied to a class, interface, or struct, the members specified can be accessed dynamically on instances returned from calling on instances of that class, interface, or struct.
If the attribute is applied to a method it's treated as a special case and it implies the attribute should be applied to the "this" parameter of the method. As such the attribute should only be used on instance methods of types assignable to System.Type (or string, but no methods will use it there).
